comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We're looking for your help! Please help us identify the location in this photograph in the comments below.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: Wesley Paulson of the National Capital Trolley Museum identified this image on our blog today as Calvert Street NW, north of the bridge over Rock Creek Park, and can be referenced on pages 30, 120 and 134 of “100 Years of Capital Traction” by Roy King. Here's a view of the same location today on Google Maps: View Larger Map

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
The title has been updated!

Susannah
Smithsonian Institution Archives

comment.author: 33722706@N04
comment._content:
"  Wesley Paulson of the National Capital Trolley Museum identified this image on our blog today as Calvert Street NW, north of the bridge over Rock Creek Park, and can be referenced on pages 30, 120 and 134 of “100 Years of Capital Traction” by Roy King.  "

This view  looks east on Calvert St. from Connecticut Avenue, one can see the original 1891 "Calvert St. bridge" which was replaced in 1935. The link view looks south on Connecticut Ave. from Calvert St. with the Taft bridge in the distance which never carried streetcar traffic.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: Thank you for your comment, robspost!

comment.author: 33722706@N04
comment._content:
Thanks to the map on page 125 of LeRoy O.King’s (jr.) excellent documentation; “100 Years Of Capital Traction” one can trace the Connecticut Avenue streetcar line in it’s entirety. This streetcar route operated from the 7th St. wharves at NW P and Water streets, 7th St to Florida Ave, U St., 18th St. to Calvert St. to the Rock Creek loop where the change-over from underground conduit to overhead trolley wire was made. The car then proceeded westward across the original 1891 steel/iron bridge to Connecticut Avenue**,  the car then turned onto Connecticut Ave. to Chevy Chase Circle and/or Chevy Chase Lake..

    ** (it was here that the old photograph was made looking east on Calvert St. with the tracks curving to the left and onto Connecticut Avenue)

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
Thank you robspost for the information and suggested caption. Thanks to your research, the caption is now changed above! We appreciate all of our Flickr Commons sleuths out there.

Catherine Shteynberg
Smithsonian Institution Archives
